Learn how council tax works and what it pays for.

What is council tax

Council tax is a property-based tax charged on homes in England, Scotland, and Wales. Every home is put into a band based on what it was worth on 1 April 1991.

The amount you pay depends on which band your property is in and who lives there. Council tax helps pay for local services that benefit everyone in the community.

What your council tax pays for

Your council tax bill includes charges from different organisations. Each one provides different services.

Gloucester City Council

The City Council uses its share to provide local services like:

  • Waste collection and recycling
  • Street cleaning
  • Parks and open spaces
  • Leisure facilities
  • Environmental health
  • Planning and building control
  • Housing services

Gloucestershire County Council

The County Council gets the largest share and provides services like:

  • Adult social care
  • Children's services
  • Schools and education
  • Highways and transport
  • Libraries
  • Trading standards
  • Fire and rescue

Police and Crime Commissioner

This part of your bill pays for police services across Gloucestershire.

Parish or Town Councils

Some areas have an extra charge for parish or town councils (like Quedgeley). They provide very local services like:

  • Community facilities
  • Local parks and playgrounds
  • Village halls

The council tax year

Council tax runs for a financial year, from 1 April to 31 March the following year.

Your bill shows the full year's charge. You can choose to pay in 10 monthly instalments (April to January) or 12 monthly instalments (April to March).

The law and council tax

Legal basis

Council tax is set by law under the Local Government Finance Act 1992. This means we must charge council tax on all homes, and people must pay it.

How charges are set

Each year, councils work out how much money they need to provide services. They then set the council tax charge to help cover these costs.

The amount is agreed by:

  • Gloucester City Council (for city services)
  • Gloucestershire County Council (for county services)
  • The Police and Crime Commissioner (for police services)
  • Your parish or town council (if you have one)

Limits on increases

The government sets limits on how much councils can increase council tax each year. If a council wants to increase it by more than the limit, they must hold a local vote (referendum).

Who sets your band

Your property's council tax band is set by the Valuation Office Agency (VOA), which is part of central government. The council does not set bands.

Bands are based on what your property was worth on 1 April 1991, not what it's worth now. This is the same for all properties in England.

See all council tax bands

Who has to pay

Council tax is a property tax. The person who lives in the property (or owns it if it's empty) must pay.

Order of liability

If more than one person could be responsible, we use this order to decide:

  1. A resident who owns the property (freeholder)
  2. A resident who is a leaseholder
  3. A resident who is a tenant
  4. A resident with a licence to live there
  5. Any other resident
  6. The owner (if no one lives there)

Example: If you own and live in your home, you pay. If you rent, you (the tenant) pay, not the landlord.

More about liability when you move

Exemptions and discounts

Some people and properties can get reductions on their council tax.

Exemptions

Some properties are exempt from council tax (no charge at all). For example:

  • Properties lived in only by full-time students
  • Properties that cannot legally be lived in
  • Annexes lived in by elderly or disabled relatives

Discounts

Some situations qualify for a discount. For example:

  • 25% off if you live alone (single person discount)
  • Disabled band reduction if you need extra space

See all discounts and exemptions

Council Tax Support

Council Tax Support is different from discounts and exemptions. It's a benefit that helps people on low incomes pay their council tax.

You can get Council Tax Support even if you're working. The amount you get depends on your income, savings, and circumstances.

Find out about Council Tax Support

What happens if you don't pay

Council tax is not optional. By law, you must pay it if you're liable.

If you don't pay, we have legal powers to collect what you owe. This can include:

  • Court action to get a liability order
  • Using enforcement agents (bailiffs)
  • Taking money from your wages or benefits

Having trouble paying? Contact us as soon as possible. We can help if you get in touch early.
